results.title: Let me out
results.creator_credit: Kiar Eegan, Gregg Torkington and Stuart Griffiths
results.brief_description: A montage of animated images that describe a city without hope filled with loneliness, prostitutes and desperate people. But, is the situation really that bad? Animated and produced by the team: Kiar Eegan, Gregg Torkington and Stuart Griffiths.

results.title: Let me die, again
results.brief_description: A young man dreams of himself as embdying the spirit and the flesh of the great opera diva, Maria Callas. But in the harsh reality of the mirror he has to confront his body, his maleness and the past. A richly stylised tribute to queer’s legacy of fascination and subversion in the romance of opera.

results.title: Let it bee: Concerto in C Minor by Vivaldi
results.brief_description: Excerpt from Bruno Bozzetto’s “Allegro Non Troppo”. A domesticated honey-bee prepares a picnic with wine and cheese but is disturbed by a romancing couple bent also on picnicking. Music from Vivaldi. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Let hi-speed clean your oven!
results.brief_description: An advertising film presenting Mrs Housewife attempting to remove built up grease from her oven. All her efforts fail until she tries ‘Hi-Speed’ stove cleaner which dissolves baked on grease without damaging the enamel. Provides an insight into mid 20th Century marketing and the representation of women in advertising.

results.title: Let habit help
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Personal Side of Safety”.
Safety lies in the kind of habits we have - good habits or dangerous habits. Shows the worker how to analyse themself - how to build up good habits that lead to safety.

results.title: Let battle commence
results.brief_description: The history of the making of a cartoon by the amateur Grasshopper Group - a number of people interested in animation. Covers all aspects of the project from the initial idea, through to the finished cartoon, “The Battle of Wangapore”, which is then shown in its entirety. (See also Title Code 001057 “The Battle of Wangapore”).

results.title: Let's visit Rum Jungle [Colour]
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: An instructional film for classroom use. Gives an account of the processing of uranium ore at Rum Jungle, Northern Territory, pointing out the importance of this material in the world today. Describes the development of the mine deposit to the present day. Shots taken at the mine and in the plant show mining of the ore and the processes it passes through until the uranium concentrate is isolated. Nuclear power depends on supplies of uranium and Australia is one of the few producing countries. The peacetime applications of nuclear power are almost unlimited.

results.title: Let's visit Rum Jungle [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: Deals with uranium mining at Rum Jungle in the Northern Territory. Includes scenes of the crushing and refining of the ore, and shows the living conditions of the workers in the area. Atomic power depends on supplies of uranium and Australia is one of the few producing countries. The peacetime applications of atomic power are almost unlimited.

results.title: Let's visit Darwin
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Modern social studies”.
An instructional film for classroom use. Portrays Darwin as it is today (1957) - a vigorous expanding town and capital of the Northern Territory. A typical Darwin family is seen at daily tasks, and the way in which they spend their work and leisure hours is observed.
